sec.title: Appreciating event ambiguity
sec.p: In a fundamental sense, the members of the jury determine a lawyer’s success in the courtroom. How jurors view events in the courtroom is therefore critical; it shapes their perceptions of the case, their deliberations, and ultimately, their verdict. Of course, juries generally are not composed of legal experts but rather of “ordinary citizens” whose interpretations of events transpiring in the courtroom may be shaped by any number of factors. According to my data, neophyte trial lawyers are less appreciative of this point than their highly experienced counterparts. As it turns out, novice lawyers are likely to make unfounded or overly hasty assumptions about whether events are “good” or “bad” in terms of their effect on the jury. In line with this perspective, informant 11 discussed how he tends to view a number of events as “bad things,” and how he typically reacts to such events with thoughts like, “Oh shit, I wish that didn’t get said just now” (Table 4). These rather polarizing views of courtroom events can lead to confusion when it turns out that jury members have not interpreted the event as the lawyer expected they would. For example, an inexperienced lawyer noted his bewilderment when members of the jury did not resonate with a line of argument he thought was “clear as a bell” and thus good for the case he was presenting (Table 4).

In contrast, experienced lawyers understand better that jurors may interpret courtroom events in any number of ways—which are sometimes difficult to predict. That is, while an unexpected event—a witness lying under oath, for example—might seem at first blush either damaging or helpful to one’s case, the net impact of this event is actually somewhat uncertain. As informant 46 mentioned, “You’re not sure how the jury takes it” (Table 4).

Coinciding with this insight, experienced lawyers also tend to understand that juror interpretations of unfolding events are connected to how lawyers themselves engage with or respond to the event that has occurred. Consequently, experienced lawyers recognize that although they cannot know for sure how jury members interpret events, it is within their control to shape or frame these interpretations. Thus, as one experienced lawyer explained, trials are not as much about presenting the jury with facts as they are about telling a story around those facts and shaping the story on an almost moment-to-moment basis. This lawyer conceded, “I don’t care what the facts are; when I’m in the courtroom, it’s all about me, and I’ve got to put on the right kind of show, the right way” (33). In clarifying this comment, informant 33 explained that part of the “show” he is putting on involves getting the jury members to view events in line with his case. With respect to witness testimony, he stated, “I have to spin—as the word might be—spin what I’m getting from the witness to impress the jury that what they’ve just heard is very significant or not significant.”

More generally, my data indicate that experienced trial lawyers appreciate the ambiguity of courtroom events. As used here, the term “appreciating event ambiguity” encompasses both the broad recognition that courtroom events are oftentimes ambiguous and open to multiple interpretations and the more acute insight that lawyers themselves can shape the event interpretations drawn by jury members (a distinction reflected in the data structure summarized in Table 2). In appreciating event ambiguity, trial lawyers understand there are many possible ways to integrate courtroom events with their overarching theme or story.

These observations should not overshadow the fact that, in at least some instances, the meaning of an event for the outcome of a trial is largely unequivocal. For example, some of my informants discussed instances in which the accused admitted that he or she was guilty or liable—an event that, in essence, put an end to the trial. Moreover, my findings do not indicate that highly experienced lawyers are always comfortable with unexpected developments, owing to their appreciation for event ambiguity. After all, even the most experienced lawyers may wish that some events (e.g., key witnesses failing to appear in court) had not occurred during a trial no matter how well they attempted to connect these events to the theme or details of their case. However, what my data do suggest is that courtroom events are generally subject to a much wider range of interpretations than meets the eye of the novice trial lawyer. To put this more generally, in a social context filled with unpredictability, events contain several possible interpretations—some of which may prove quite useful, if identified. As discussed below, one’s ability to draw these useful interpretations stems from one’s response repertoire.

sec.title: Building a response repertoire
sec.p: As noted, experienced trial lawyers recognize that the way jurors interpret courtroom events is, to some degree, related to how lawyers themselves interpret and respond to these events. However, for lawyers to achieve and maintain a high level of attentional integration, they must not only appreciate the ambiguity of courtroom events; they must also be able to capitalize on that ambiguity. That is, lawyers must have the ability to influence the jury’s interpretations of events in a manner favorable to their case. As it turns out, this ability is another byproduct of trial law experience. Specifically, in accruing experience, trial lawyers develop a repertoire of possible responses to courtroom events. In building this “response repertoire” (Weick, 1988), lawyers become increasingly adept at taking ambiguous events and signaling to jurors that these events fit their case.

A lawyer’s response repertoire may constitute a range of skills. For example, as suggested earlier, lawyers may learn through experience that not all objectionable statements call for objections. In some instances, not objecting provides precisely the opportunity they have been looking for. Along these lines, Table 4 includes a quote from an inexperienced lawyer (02) describing the challenge of “picking battles” in terms of when to object and also includes quotes from experienced lawyers (29 and 42) that provide further evidence for why knowing when—and when not—to object is an important part of a lawyer’s response repertoire as well as how this skill is associated with experience.
Experience may teach lawyers to use objections skillfully in another respect as well. On this point, a highly experienced litigator stated the following.

disp-quote.p: One reason I object is to let the jury know some type of opinion, or almost have a dialog with the jury. I mean, I might stand up and object, “Your Honor, that is not based on personal knowledge, and it’s irrelevant to the issues the jury has to decide. This guy was not there. He doesn’t know what was said. He’s just speculating.” I’m making a speech to the jury, you know, that’s what I’m doing. (45)

sec.p: As suggested through this example, informant 45 has developed a particular skill within his response repertoire—using objections to have a “dialog” with the jury—that permits him to see certain situations for what they are to him—namely opportunities.

Another component of experienced lawyers’ response repertoires concerns their ability to act. A common form of acting among experienced trial lawyers is acting as though courtroom events align with or buttress one’s case, no matter what the event means from a strictly legal standpoint. For example, a lawyer may portray an event as deeply meaningful when, in fact, it is a relatively minor point given the overall context and details of the case. Along these lines, informant 41 discussed how an otherwise inconsequential statement—such as a police officer testifying that he or she did not attempt to collect fingerprints (in a situation where doing so might not have been feasible)—could be construed in one’s favor by acting like “this is really important and really critical” (Table 4).
In a similar vein, lawyers may act in response to the judge’s rulings. Informant 16 described his reaction when he first witnessed such acting in practice.

disp-quote.p: I was amazed when I first saw this…It was the lawyer who can make, in front of a jury, can make every decision the judge makes appear to be the one he wanted…In a jury trial [there] are what are called sidebar conferences where the parties go up and there’s an issue before the court and the court doesn’t want the jury to hear about what the deliberation process, so the court makes the ruling in secret. Invariably one side or the other will have lost that argument. [This] lawyer [made] it appear that all is won by the way he walks back to the table, by voice, he says, “Thank you, your Honor.”

sec.p: Informant 16 went on to describe this particular skill—acting like whatever answer you get is the answer you wanted—as a “function of experience,” a skill learned through being in the courtroom and having “seen somebody pull that off.”

While acting skills among trial lawyers might seem commonplace, in actuality many lawyers—particularly inexperienced ones—have not adequately developed the ability to act effectively. This is unfortunate, according to informant 18, because acting may help lawyers avoid situations like the following.

disp-quote.p: When [unexpected] things happen, [it’s] how you handle it. Some people will just freak out, and their eyes will get real white, and then they’ll just, they don’t know what to do. And they’ll sit down and everybody in the courtroom can pick up on “ooh, that wasn’t good for them.”

sec.p: This statement not only highlights the importance of “knowing what to do” as unexpected situations arise (e.g., acting as though the event is beneficial for—or at least inconsequential to—one’s case), but also reinforces the claim that jury members take their cues from the lawyer to determine whether events have helped or hurt the lawyer’s case.

With that said, my findings do not suggest that relatively inexperienced litigators are unaware of the importance of acting. For example, informant 11 discussed how, when faced with an unexpected development, he tries to “keep a poker face” (Table 4). However, for the most part, inexperienced trial lawyers described acting as more of a reactionary process than a method for conveying that unfolding events have strengthened one’s case. In part, this is perhaps because inexperienced lawyers are less appreciative of the ambiguity of courtroom events and thus more likely to think that unexpected events call for damage control rather than exploitation. As stated by informant 11, “There’s always the initial reaction… ‘Okay, is this as bad as I think it is?’ And then, ‘How do I kind of minimize whatever damage it is?’ I guess I’m always thinking about that in terms of bad things rather than good things.” This reaction is understandable given informant 11’s admission that, when a witness’s testimony goes awry, his “heart sinks” (Table 4).

Taken together, the observations offered in this section indicate that experienced trial lawyers possess a larger response repertoire than neophyte trial lawyers. This matters because, as suggested, large response repertoires may heighten attentional integration. The skills constituting lawyers’ response repertoires (e.g., acting) enable them to take advantage of ambiguous events by crafting interpretations of these events that favor their case. In the absence of a response repertoire, a lawyer may lack the means to integrate ongoing events with the theme of his or her case and, for that matter, may be oblivious to the opportunities that attentional integration might permit. Revealing an awareness of this issue, a relatively inexperienced lawyer bemoaned his inability to spot opportunities that he believed his more experienced counterparts could seize.

disp-quote.p: What happens is, as you get a lawyer who is…more experienced [and] also more crafty, then you’re not seeing the same things they are. So because they’re just—they’ll have a different perception on things, and you’re fighting a different battle than what they’re fighting. And so, that’s when you’re really at I think a big disadvantage—it’s not just age; it’s more experience. (09)

sec.p: In short, the response repertoires lawyers gain through experience provide them with the resources necessary to construct useful interpretations of ambiguous events and to identify such opportunities in the first place. Through the discussion that follows, I unpack this point further and consider a number of implications of my findings.

sec.title: Discussion

disp-quote.p: When people expand their repertoire, they improve their alertness. And when they see more, they are in a better position to spot weak signals which suggest that an issue is turning into a problem which might well turn into a crisis if it is not contained. (Weick, 2006, p. 1724)

sec.p: In some respects, this claim captures key components of the findings reported here; at the same time, it brings into relief the novelty of these findings vis-a-vis related lines of inquiry. On the former point, through my research I elaborated theory surrounding experience-based qualities of attention in a dynamic work setting (trial law). In doing so, I found that by increasing their capacities—for example, through developing rule-following skills and building a response repertoire—trial lawyers may achieve greater alertness, not simply to events in their work setting but also to the opportunities residing within these events that can be tapped and exploited. This is because the capacities born through experience enhance trial lawyers’ attentional breadth and attentional integration—key qualities of attention in a courtroom.

On the latter point—concerning the novelty of my findings—I found that the “weak signals” in my research context are not always, or even generally, signs of a crisis. Through acquiring experience, trial lawyers tend to move past simplistic conceptions of courtroom events as “harmful” or “helpful” by recognizing that the ultimate meaning of such events is determined at least to some degree by their own interpretations and responses. In this sense, and perhaps dissimilar to contexts involving significant risk of physical harm or disaster (e.g., high reliability organizations—Weick et al., 1999), trial law is perhaps less about noticing subtle signs of danger and more a matter of seeing how the events one notices can be turned to one’s advantage. Put differently, in a context defined by persuasion or social influence, one may view almost any event opportunistically, depending on the qualities of attention it receives. For this reason, the expression “things seen and unseen” as used in the paper title is as much a statement about interpretation as it is about noticing.

It is also a statement about research on attention. As noted at the outset of this paper, much research has focused on issues concerning the direction of attention. While essential and enduring, such research has obscured from view matters concerning the qualities of attention. By turning the spotlight toward this topic, the study reported here illuminates specific qualities of attention (i.e., attentional breadth and attentional integration) that have received only limited scholarly consideration and reveals avenues by which these qualities may be enhanced via experience.

Collectively, my findings carry a range of implications. In particular, these findings expand the catalog of qualities of attention and provide a basis for comparing one quality of attention to another—a task I undertake below. Furthermore, as I later highlight, the concepts of attentional breadth and attention integration that surfaced through my study connect to and inform a number of lines of organizational scholarship.

sec.title: Cataloging qualities of attention
sec.p: My findings point to attentional breadth and attentional integration as key qualities of attention in trial law. These qualities of attention both complement and build upon previous research surrounding attentional qualities, and invite comparisons that may help scholars develop a more comprehensive typology of attention and its qualities. Perhaps most fundamentally, some qualities of attention may be primarily related to noticing events while others are more directly linked to interpreting events. As my findings suggest, attentional breadth fits the former category while attentional integration is paradigmatic of the latter.

By its nature, attentional breadth entails attending to a wide range or spectrum of events. In this sense, it is concerned with noticing and, more specifically, with noticing more rather than less. The claim that attentional breadth represents a quality of attention is important as it brackets this concept from research on the direction of attention. Attentional breadth implies that, although a number of people may be attending to the same scene (i.e., their attention is generally focused in the same direction), some may be capturing more scene-related events than others. For this reason, it represents a notable quality of attention—one that, as argued, may be conducive to performance in dynamic work settings. At a neurocognitive level, attentional breadth is perhaps buttressed by executive attention (Rueda et al., 2005). Executive attention permits individuals to switch between stimuli in rapid succession, thus pursuing multiple, though related, objectives almost simultaneously (Ocasio, 2011). Through further research, scholars might demonstrate direct linkages between attentional breadth and executive attention.

Attentional breadth is not the only quality of attention pertinent to noticing. As discussed earlier, scholars have discussed another such quality of attention—attentional stability. While attentional stability—which implies steadfast, unwavering attention to a particular target or object (Weick & Sutcliffe, 2006)—did not emerge from my data in the same fashion as attentional breadth, it is nevertheless plausible that attentional stability does, in fact, matter in the courtroom (as well as in other dynamic environments). After all, in the absence of at least some level of attentional stability, events may go unregistered even when attention is directed their way. This point is perhaps implicit in lawyers’ remarks on the importance of listening carefully to what witnesses are saying and watching what other people in the courtroom are doing. Most likely, certain features of the research context led attentional breadth and not attentional stability to emerge prominently in my data. As discussed, a critical attention-related challenge trial lawyers encounter is focusing their attention widely enough to capture a number of ongoing events—a challenge that calls for a high level of attentional breadth. Even so, these observations suggest an important point of clarification. Namely, attentional breadth and attentional stability are not necessarily at odds. One quality facilitates noticing more events; the other helps to ensure that the details of noticed events are registered in full.

Next, the other quality of attention that surfaced in my study—attentional integration—bears considering. As suggested by my findings, attentional integration is linked to the interpretation side of attention. In this sense, attentional integration may be related to attentional vividness. As discussed earlier, attentional vividness concerns the richness or complexity of representations one applies to events (Weick & Sutcliffe, 2006). In other words, it is an interpretation-related quality of attention. What makes attentional integration unique, however, is that it is story directed. In other words, it involves identifying how ongoing events may equate with the message, theme, or story one seeks to convey. As such, attentional integration is of particular relevance for tasks involving influence, persuasion, or storytelling. To some degree, one may find such tasks in negotiations, sales, teaching, political debate, and certain leadership situations (e.g., “town hall” meetings).

Attentional integration is also noteworthy in that it shapes whether individuals construe events as “good” or “bad.” Indeed, owing to different levels of attentional integration, a trial law veteran might well interpret an event viewed as bad by a neophyte trial lawyer as good. With a nod to Shakespeare, it is perhaps generally true that, in a dynamic work environment rife with storytelling or social influence, “there’s nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.” For this very reason, the presence—or the absence—of attentional integration exerts a fundamental influence on whether one interprets unfolding events as boon or as bane.

Beyond informing existing theory focusing on the qualities of attention, the specific qualities uncovered through my study—attentional breadth and attentional integration—contribute to and, in some respects, challenge related lines of scholarship in management and organizational studies. Taking stock of this point, I examine below the implications of each quality of attention across a number of research domains.

sec.title: Implications concerning attentional breadth
sec.p: Before one can interpret events, one must first notice them (Starbuck & Milliken, 1988). My findings suggest that trial lawyers are able to attend to a larger number of events in the courtroom as their attentional breadth widens with experience. As described here, the increase in attentional breadth associated with experience occurs through a reduction in stress and an increase in rule-following automaticity. Each of these mechanisms deserves further comment. With regard to stress, my findings suggest that high stress levels compromise attentional breadth (see Staw, Sandelands, & Dutton, 1981). Even so, my findings do not necessarily imply that stress and attentional breadth are inversely related. On the contrary, it is possible that some baseline of stress helps individuals view their surroundings broadly. For example, in the near absence of stress, boredom may arise. This may cause a redirection of attention toward targets such as daydreams or fantasies largely disconnected from the details of one’s surroundings (Kane et al., 2007). That said, my data do not speak to the effect of low levels of stress on attentional breadth because my informants viewed stress as an inherent aspect of most cases they tried. Even lawyers who had tried many cases mentioned that they still feel some degree of stress during their trials. More generally, it is worth noting that many dynamic performance contexts are, by their very nature, stressful settings (Brehmer, 1992). Thus, for individuals operating in dynamic contexts there seems to be a greater likelihood that high rather than low stress will detract from attentional breadth.

The connection between automatic rule following and attentional breadth also merits discussion. Some lines of research suggest that the acquisition of skill automaticity may lead individuals to mentally depart from the present moment and devote thought to recollections of the past or expectations about the future (Smallwood & Schooler, 2006; Wood, Quinn, & Kashy, 2002). As such, one might assume that rule-following automaticity would narrow attentional breadth in trial law. It seems likely, however, that particular features of my research context may account for why I found that automaticity enhances rather than limits attentional breadth. Perhaps most fundamentally, because courtroom trials are dynamic environments, a lawyer’s performance depends on noticing a large number of events. Hence, trial lawyers tend to focus the attention freed via rule-following automaticity to the myriad courtroom events surrounding them, as opposed to mentally withdrawing from the situation. More generally, many dynamic situations—including not only courtroom trials but also emergency response operations (Drabek, 1985) and organizational crises (Weick, 1988)—involve high stakes, rendering it costly to withdraw attention from unfolding events.

The enhancing effect of automaticity on attentional breadth witnessed here dovetails with research observations made in other dynamic environments. For example, as individuals develop proficiency in driving an automobile, their driving skills become increasingly automatic (Dreyfus & Dreyfus, 2005). This automaticity frees attentional resources and thus permits drivers to attend to a wide range of stimuli such as road conditions and other vehicles. Likewise, improvisational stage actors learn and internalize a set of principles such as the “rule of agreement”—the notion that one should never disagree with or act counter to a suggestion offered by another. In learning to apply such rules automatically, improvisational actors free attention such that they can focus more widely on the actions surrounding them rather than solely on what to say next (Vera & Crossan, 2004). Furthermore, scholars have proposed that, at an organizational level, relatively “less-mindful” (or automatic) practices may enhance attentiveness to unexpected cues or events and permit organizations to respond flexibly as such events arise (Levinthal & Rerup, 2006). My findings complement such claims by suggesting that the effect of automatic practices on attentional breadth may hold at an individual level of analysis as well. As such, my research hints at the microfoundations (Rerup & Feldman, 2011) of certain qualities of attention (e.g., attentional breadth) one might find in certain organizations. More broadly, my findings suggest that in some contexts automaticity girds, rather than erodes, attentional breadth.

sec.title: Implications concerning attentional integration
sec.p: While attentional breadth facilitates noticing more events, attentional integration enables individuals to recognize the opportunities such events present. My findings indicate that, at least in trial law, attentional integration becomes more common as individuals accrue relevant work experience. I found that two mechanisms account for this link: appreciating event ambiguity and building a response repertoire. While the former mechanism pertains to the insight that the meanings associated with courtroom events are not independent of how lawyers respond to these events, the latter mechanism concerns the skills that permit lawyers to capitalize on this insight. Thus, in gaining trial experience, lawyers not only become adept at seeing events in a self-serving manner (see Rudolph, Morrison, & Carroll, 2009), they also become active “sensegivers” (Gioia & Chittipeddi, 1991), communicating to jurors the meanings of ongoing events as they relate to and reinforce the case they put forward.

This connection to sensegiving raises the possibility that beyond the storytelling and persuasion-related contexts noted earlier, attentional integration may be relevant to more traditional occupational and organizational settings as well—settings in which sensegiving and related processes such as narrative construction and issue selling have received scholarly investigation (e.g., Dunford & Jones, 2000; Dutton, Ashford, O’Neill, Hayes, & Wierba, 1997; Maitlis & Lawrence, 2007). Research suggests that sensegiving may constitute an “integrative” activity. For example, during organizational change efforts, senior managers construct narratives that serve to integrate ongoing organizational events with the broader change-related objectives they aim to promote (Sonenshein, 2010). Similarly, in attempting to convince top managers to attend to specific issues, middle managers may attempt to integrate or “bundle” their issues of concern with agendas or goals already receiving traction in the organization (Dutton, Ashford, O’Neill, & Lawrence, 2001).

Dynamic performance contexts, such as trial law, may amplify the challenges of sensegiving. As noted, dynamic settings call for rapid and adaptive decision making and offer little time for reflection. These settings expose an under-explored feature of sensegiving—its attentional foundations. My findings indicate that, to some degree, sensegiving is rooted in attentional integration. That is, to construct a compelling narrative or sell an issue one must be able to see opportunities for integrating an observed event with the broader story one seeks to tell. The litigators in my sample reported becoming more capable of doing this through the experiences they accrued. More generally, this raises the possibility that sensegiving behaviors exhibited in organizations are rooted not only in leadership agendas and vested interests, but also in the experiences accrued by sensegiving actors.

Despite the potentially wide-ranging applications of attentional integration and its role in sensegiving, this particular quality of attention may nonetheless be more useful in some task domains than others. As suggested, in trial law the interpretations drawn by lawyers (and jurors) grant meaning to events. While interpretation is likewise critical to the construction of event-related meanings by organizational decision makers (George, Chattopadhyay, Sitkin, & Barden, 2006; Jackson & Dutton, 1988; Plambeck & Weber, 2010), trial law is somewhat distinct in that, due to its storytelling and persuasion foundations, what represents a threat to one lawyer could be interpreted just as legitimately as an opportunity by one operating at a higher level of attentional integration. This is because there is little or no industry or field-level “environment” beyond the courtroom itself. Therefore, as noted earlier, the demands associated with trial law are rather different from those concerned with spotting potential signals of organizational crisis. Of course, even in a crisis situation, interpretation-related processes may either amplify or attenuate the magnitude of the crisis insofar as managerial interpretations shape organizational responses (Weick, 1988) and, ultimately, organizational learning (Rerup, 2009). However, when it comes to crisis avoidance or mitigation, attentional integration may not be the most desirable quality of attention. While attentional integration may engender a level of opportunism useful in contexts driven by storytelling or persuasion, this quality of attention may also prevent one from interpreting events as potential threats when it is critical to do precisely that (e.g., scanning for weak signals that portend a potential crisis). This suggests that, as useful as attentional integration appears to be in trial law, it may carry risks worth considering in certain task domains.

sec.title: Limitations and future research
sec.p: Inductive studies are often thought to be limited in their generalizability to other contexts (Eisenhardt & Graebner, 2007) and the present study is no exception. Even so, there is some likelihood that these findings will generalize to other professions and occupations involving storytelling or persuasion (e.g., negotiations, debate). Further research is needed, however, to verify this possibility. In addition, it is unclear whether the findings presented here would hold in non-dynamic settings. This is a key issue because people do not always operate in dynamic work environments. Indeed, litigators often perform tasks under relatively non-dynamic conditions including preparing witnesses for trials, crafting opening and closing statements, and making pre-trial motions. As such, research is needed to examine whether and how experience is connected to attentional breadth and attentional integration in non-dynamic or “static” settings.

Next, it bears noting that my data do not permit causal inferences (e.g., reduced stress causes wide attentional breadth). Therefore, although my informants perceived causal relationships between job experience and specific qualities of attention (Figure 1), I have taken care to avoid causal language wherever possible. For example, I avoided using the terms “positive relationship” and “negative relationship” (terms associated with a theory testing, quantitative research approach). Through further research, particularly longitudinal studies, scholars could test the causal structure of the connections between work experience and various qualities of attention.

Along related lines, scholars have noted specific limitations associated with using self-report data (e.g., research interviews) to capture cognitive processes (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977). For example, personal accounts of cognitive-level phenomena are vulnerable to memory errors (Schacter, 1999) and may yield incomplete representations of the phenomena being studied (Robinson & Clore, 2002). As such, my informants’ descriptions of the qualities of attention—and the experience-based mechanisms associated with them—are subject to questions concerning veridicality fundamentally linked to the research methodology employed. Perhaps by adopting other methodologies, such as neurophysiological approaches, researchers could circumvent these limitations and develop an account of attention and its qualities that either validates or challenges the findings reported here.

Finally, although my data suggest fairly direct connections between trial law experience and the attentional qualities of note (via the mechanisms described here), it is possible that certain factors may influence the extent to which experience shapes these qualities of attention either within my research setting or in other occupational contexts. In evaluating this possibility, researchers could examine whether factors such as “reflective learning” (Schön, 1983) or “learning goal orientation” (Dweck & Leggett, 1988) influence how rapidly or comprehensively individuals develop attentional breadth or attentional integration as they accrue job-related experience.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite emerging interest in the topic, the qualities that attention may take on have received limited investigation. Through the study reported here, I explored qualities of attention pertinent to individuals working in a dynamic setting. In doing so, I identified two key qualities—attentional breadth and attentional integration—and revealed experience-related mechanisms through which these qualities may arise. Of particular note, I found that, within the focal context, how attention is brought to bear determines the distinction between threats and opportunities. This suggests that, in achieving certain qualities of attention, individuals are able to see not only more events but also more possibilities.

list-item.p: 1. How long have you been a litigator?
2. Have you always worked at this law firm? [If not] Where else have you worked as a litigator?
3. What type of law do you practice?
4. Approximately how many cases have you tried in your career?

5. I’m interested in what you pay attention to when you’re trying a case. Would you please talk about this issue? [Prompts: What things are most important to pay attention to? Are there some things you try to ignore?]

6. Is focusing your attention where it needs to be easy? Difficult? Do you tend to notice things that could hurt your case? Things that could help it? What is the difference between something that helps versus something that hurts your case?
7. Is the difference between something that helps versus hurts your case “black or white”? Is there ambiguity about whether something is helping or hurting your case? Please elaborate.
8. Can you recall a time that you happened to hear or notice something really important going on during a trial? [If so] Please elaborate.
9. Can you recall a time that you failed to hear or notice something important going on during a trial until it was too late? [If so] Please elaborate.

10. Do you feel like you’re fully “there” yet in terms of your ability to focus your attention effectively during trials? What might other lawyers be picking up on that you’re missing? What might you be seeing that other lawyers are missing?

11. Has what you focus on in the courtroom changed as you’ve gained more trial experience? If so, how? [Prompts: Are there specific things you focus more on now than you used to? Are there specific things you focus on less? Is it easier to notice some things now? Harder to notice some things now?]

12. Has your experience affected other things about how you try cases? Does experience help you? Hurt you? What are the consequences of experience as you see them? [Prompts: Are certain things easier to do? More difficult to do?]
13. Can you think about what it feels like to try a case in the courtroom? Has the feeling of trying a case changed in any way as you’ve gained trial experience?

14. From the standpoint of trying cases, what types of experience matter most to you (for example, personally trying cases, watching other trials, talking with other lawyers, participating in training programs)?

15. We’ve gone through a number of questions concerning what you pay attention to in the courtroom and how you feel that your work experiences have affected you. Are there any other thoughts you’d like to share or points you didn’t have a chance to mention?
